subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: The Canadian Net-Zero Emissions Accountability Act, adopted by Parliament in July 2021, formalizes Canada's target to achieve net-zero emissions by the year 2050 and establishes a series of interim emissions reduction targets at 5-year milestones toward that goal.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Canada's 2021 NDC includes a target of reducing emissions in absolute levels by 40 to 45% below 2005 levels by 2030. Additionally, Canada is committed to reducing its emissions to net zero by 2050.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: Clean energy investment is focused around Canada's massive hydropower resources, and much of the country's clean energy policy reflects this hydro capacity. In the last decade or so, Canadian provinces have adopted various clean energy policies to increase the share of power from renewable resources and reduce emissions from the power sector.

Any gaps in Canada’s renewable energy goals that aren't met with hydropower resources are filled by solar and wind resources, mostly by public utilities or large independent power producers. Thanks to transparent tariffs and energy data, investment in Canadian energy markets is diverse and competitive.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: Canada's clean energy policy is mostly addressed on a provincial level. Each province controls its own electricity generation, distribution and energy market and sets its own clean energy targets. Saskatchewan, Alberta, British Columbia, Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island have renewable energy goals. Manitoba, Ontario, and Newfoundland do not.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: In Manitoba and Newfoundland, the majority of electricity generated comes from hydropower. Ontario had a renewable energy feed-in tariff that ended in 2017 and has the most installed wind (5GW) and solar capacity (3GW) in the country. Many Canadian provinces have vast quantities of pumped hydropower capacity, limiting the push to build out additional renewable energy or energy storage capacity.

subsections.title: Power market
text: On a country-wide basis, hydropower supplies about 60% of total generation in Canada. As the country has not recently experienced the effects of droughts or other climate change-related natural disasters that could impact the output of hydropower resources, the dominance of hydro as a share of Canada's power mix is unlikely to change in the near term. Pumped hydropower resources provide necessary flexibility to provincial liberalized power markets, and about 35% of the country's power generation comes from inflexible thermal generating sources. There is little pressure to begin building significant battery resources. The biggest players in Canada's power markets are public utilities like Hydro-Quebec, Ontario Power Generation, and BC Hydro.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Factors such as population growth, post-Covid-19 economic expansion and increasing use of electrical appliances and equipment are expected to drive Canada's electricity demand in coming years. Conversely, economic stagnation would suppress demand growth. In the first half of 2020, Alberta power demand averaged 4.9% below BloombergNEF's "business-as-usual" model, and Ontario was 1.6% lower. Given that the country is home to a modernized power grid with an 100% electrification rate nationally, the push for mini-grid systems is subdued and focused around smaller use cases, like remote regions or those with especially volatile grid connections.

subsections.title: EV market
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: Canada’s EV market is young. In June 2021, the Canadian government moved up its previous goal to require 100% of new light-duty cars and trucks to be zero-emitting by 2035. The original goal – set in 2019 – was to meet the 100% zero-emission transport target by 2040. The country announced the 2035 goal will be met with a mix of investment and regulation.
In coming months, Canada is set to develop interim 2025 and 2030 targets and additional mandatory measures that will be needed to achieve the updated goal.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: The buildings sector makes up about a quarter of Canada’s total energy demand. New buildings drive the country’s demand for energy services; floor area in Canada increased about 5% faster than population did in the last decade. Canada’s climate also strongly influences energy use for heating and cooling, which together represent around 65% of the sector’s energy consumption.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: The expansion of Canada’s decarbonization efforts will require greater emphasis on energy intensity improvements of existing buildings. Strategies around heating and cooling demand will play a major role in achieving ambitions for buildings in the clean energy transition.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the low-carbon heating and cooling market remains at an early stage.
